title: Periodized Nutrition for Endurance Performance
content:
**The Principle of Nutritional Periodization**

Just as training varies across the year, nutrition should adapt to support current training demands and goals. One-size-fits-all approaches leave performance on the table.

**Carbohydrate Periodization**

*Training Phase Carbohydrate Targets (g/kg bodyweight/day):*

Off-Season/Recovery:
- 3-5 g/kg/day
- Lower volume = lower fuel needs
- Focus on nutrient density over quantity

Base/Aerobic Building:
- 5-7 g/kg/day
- Supporting increased volume
- Adequate for Zone 2 adaptations

Build/Intensity Phase:
- 6-8 g/kg/day
- Higher intensity increases carb reliance
- Quality carbs around key sessions

Race Week/Competition:
- 8-12 g/kg/day (carb loading)
- Glycogen supercompensation
- Detailed protocol below

*Daily Carbohydrate Timing:*

Hard Training Day:
- Pre-workout (2-4 hrs): 1-2 g/kg
- During workout (if >90 min): 60-90 g/hr
- Post-workout (within 2 hrs): 1-1.5 g/kg
- Remaining meals: Distribute rest of daily target

Easy/Recovery Day:
- Lower total carb intake
- Distribute evenly across meals
- Can use for 'train low' adaptations if desired

**Train Low, Compete High Strategy**

*Concept:* Deliberately restrict carbohydrates for some training sessions to enhance fat oxidation and metabolic flexibility, while fully fueling for key sessions and all competitions.

*Methods:*

Sleep Low:
- Evening workout depletes glycogen
- Low-carb dinner
- Fasted morning session (Zone 2 only)
- Breaks fast with carbs post-workout

Train Low:
- Selected easy sessions with restricted carbs
- Never for high-intensity or key sessions
- Water and electrolytes only during session

Twice-a-Day Training:
- First session depletes glycogen
- Low-carb between sessions
- Second session done in depleted state

*Important Caveats:*
- Only for experienced athletes
- Never train low for intensity sessions
- Immune suppression risk if overdone
- Quality of high-intensity work suffers without carbs
- Periodize carefully: 2-3 sessions/week maximum
- Always compete with full glycogen stores

**Protein Periodization**

*Daily Targets by Phase:*

Maintenance/Off-Season:
- 1.2-1.4 g/kg/day
- Basic muscle maintenance
- Recovery from reduced training

High-Volume Training:
- 1.4-1.6 g/kg/day
- Supporting muscle repair from volume
- Spread across 4-5 meals

High-Intensity/Build Phase:
- 1.6-1.8 g/kg/day
- Higher demands from intensity
- Extra focus on post-workout protein

Weight Loss Phase:
- 1.8-2.2 g/kg/day
- Preserving muscle during deficit
- Higher protein satiety helps adherence

*Protein Timing:*
- Post-workout: 20-40g within 2 hours (leucine threshold)
- Evening/before bed: 30-40g casein or slow protein
- Spread remaining across meals (3-4 hour intervals)
- Minimum per meal: 20g (to trigger muscle protein synthesis)

**Fat Considerations**

- Minimum: 20% of calories (hormone health, absorption of fat-soluble vitamins)
- Typical range: 20-35% of calories
- Quality matters: Prioritize omega-3s, monounsaturated fats
- Timing: Lower fat around workouts (slows digestion)
- Sources: Fatty fish, olive oil, nuts, avocado

title: Race Fueling Protocols by Distance
content:
**Carbohydrate Loading Protocol**

*Classic 3-Day Protocol:*

Days 3-2 Before Race:
- 10-12 g/kg/day carbohydrate
- Reduce training volume significantly
- Low fiber to reduce GI bulk
- Familiar foods only

Day Before Race:
- 10 g/kg/day carbohydrate
- Very light activity or rest
- Hydrate well (pale urine)
- Dinner: High-carb, low-fiber, familiar

Race Morning:
- 2-4 g/kg, 2-4 hours before start
- Easily digestible carbs
- Low fat, low fiber
- Examples: Oatmeal, toast, banana, sports drink

*Signs of Successful Carb Loading:*
- Weight gain of 1-2 kg (glycogen + water)
- Feeling 'full' or slightly bloated
- Muscles feel 'pumped'

**Race Fueling by Event**

*5K-10K:*
- No in-race fueling needed
- Pre-race: Light breakfast 2-3 hours before
- Hydration: Sip water if nervous, don't overhydrate

*Half Marathon:*
- Fueling: 30-60g carbs total (1-2 gels or equivalent)
- Timing: Around 45 min and 75 min (or when passing aid stations)
- Hydration: Water at 2-3 aid stations
- Caffeine: Optional gel with caffeine at 60 min

*Marathon:*
- Target: 60-90g carbs/hour after first 45 min
- Protocol:
  - 0-30 min: Nothing or small sip
  - 30-45 min: First fuel (gel or equivalent)
  - Every 20-25 min thereafter: Continue fueling
  - Total: 4-6 gels or equivalent over race
- Hydration: Every aid station, 150-250ml
- Sodium: 500-700mg/hour minimum (more in heat)
- Caffeine: 100-200mg at mile 18-20 if struggling

*Ironman Bike Leg:*
- Target: 80-120g carbs/hour (trained gut essential)
- Mix: 60% liquid, 40% solid early; shift to liquid late
- Food examples: Bars, bananas, rice cakes, sandwiches (early)
- Shift to gels and liquids in final 1-2 hours before run
- Sodium: 500-1000mg/hour depending on conditions
- Caffeine: Strategic use, avoid overdoing

*Ironman Run:*
- Target: 60-90g carbs/hour
- Mostly gels and liquids (solids harder to tolerate running)
- Aid stations: Alternate water and sports drink
- Cola at aid stations: Acceptable caffeine/sugar source late in race
- Sodium: Continue 500-1000mg/hour

**Gut Training Protocol**

*Why Train Your Gut:*
- GI distress is leading cause of DNF in long races
- Gut adapts to processing carbs during exercise
- Can improve tolerance from 60g/hr to 90-120g/hr

*8-Week Gut Training Protocol:*

Weeks 1-2:
- Practice taking 30-40g carbs/hr during long sessions
- Use products you'll race with
- Note any GI issues

Weeks 3-4:
- Increase to 50-60g/hr
- Experiment with timing and products
- Mix glucose and fructose sources (2:1 ratio)

Weeks 5-6:
- Push toward 70-80g/hr
- Full race-simulation nutrition during long sessions
- Practice exact race-day timing

Weeks 7-8:
- Target race nutrition rate (80-90g/hr)
- Fine-tune products, timing, carrying system
- Confidence in strategy

*Multiple Carbohydrate Sources:*
- Glucose alone: Maximum absorption ~60g/hr
- Glucose + Fructose (2:1): Can absorb 90-120g/hr
- Fructose uses different intestinal transporter
- Most modern products are formulated for this

**Troubleshooting Race Nutrition**

*GI Distress:*
- Causes: Too much too fast, dehydration, high intensity, unfamiliar foods
- Prevention: Train gut, start conservative, use familiar products
- Management: Slow down, switch to water only temporarily, small sips

*Bonking (Glycogen Depletion):*
- Signs: Sudden fatigue, dizziness, inability to maintain pace
- Prevention: Adequate carb loading, start fueling early
- Recovery: Fast carbs immediately, slow down until recovered

*Hyponatremia (Low Sodium):*
- Causes: Overhydration, inadequate sodium intake
- Signs: Nausea, headache, confusion (serious: seizures)
- Prevention: Don't overdrink, include sodium in fueling
- Note: More common in slower athletes in long events

title: Post-Workout Recovery Nutrition Protocols
content:
**The Recovery Nutrition Window**

*What the Research Says:*
- Glycogen resynthesis is fastest in first 2 hours post-exercise
- Muscle protein synthesis elevated for 24-48 hours, but peaks early
- The 'anabolic window' is real but broader than often claimed
- Total daily intake matters most; timing optimizes

*When Timing Matters Most:*
- Training twice in one day (need rapid glycogen recovery)
- Another hard session within 8 hours
- Racing on consecutive days
- Very long/depleting sessions (>3 hours)

*When Timing Matters Less:*
- 24+ hours until next hard session
- Moderate training sessions
- Adequate total daily nutrition

**Immediate Post-Workout (0-30 minutes)**

*Carbohydrate:*
- Target: 1.0-1.2 g/kg (immediate)
- High glycemic for rapid absorption
- Examples: Sports drink, white rice, potatoes, recovery shake
- Why: Maximizes glycogen resynthesis rate

*Protein:*
- Target: 20-40g (0.3-0.4 g/kg)
- Complete protein with leucine (>2.5g leucine)
- Whey is fastest absorbing; other complete proteins work
- Why: Triggers muscle protein synthesis

*Practical Options:*
- Recovery shake (protein + carbs)
- Chocolate milk (good ratio, accessible)
- Greek yogurt + fruit
- Smoothie with protein

**Recovery Meal (1-2 hours post)**

*Composition:*
- Carbohydrate: 1-1.5 g/kg
- Protein: 20-40g
- Vegetables: For micronutrients, antioxidants
- Some fat: Okay now, won't impair recovery

*Example Meals:*
- Salmon, rice, roasted vegetables
- Chicken stir-fry with noodles
- Pasta with lean meat sauce and side salad
- Bean burrito bowl with rice

**Extended Recovery (Following Hours)**

*Continued Protein Distribution:*
- Every 3-4 hours: 20-40g protein
- Before bed: 30-40g slow protein (casein, cottage cheese)
- Why: Sustained muscle protein synthesis

*Glycogen Replenishment:*
- Full replenishment takes 24-48 hours
- Continue carb intake at meals
- Sleep: Glycogen resynthesis continues overnight

**Recovery Nutrition by Session Type**

*Easy/Recovery Session (<60 min, Zone 1-2):*
- Minimal specific recovery nutrition needed
- Regular meal timing sufficient
- Normal hydration

*Moderate Session (60-90 min, mixed intensity):*
- Post-workout snack: 30-40g carbs + 20g protein
- Normal meal within 2 hours
- Rehydrate: 1.5× fluid lost (weigh before/after)

*Hard Session (Intervals, Threshold, Long):*
- Immediate: Recovery shake or snack
- Meal within 2 hours: Full recovery meal
- Rehydration: Priority, include sodium
- Protein before bed if evening session

*Very Long Session (>3 hours):*
- Start recovery during cool-down if possible
- Immediate aggressive carb intake (1.2 g/kg)
- Protein every 3-4 hours for 24 hours
- Monitor hydration closely
- May take 48+ hours for full recovery

**Recovery-Enhancing Foods**

*Anti-Inflammatory:*
- Fatty fish (omega-3s)
- Tart cherry juice (reduces DOMS in studies)
- Berries (antioxidants)
- Turmeric/curcumin (with black pepper for absorption)

*Glycogen Replenishment:*
- White rice, potatoes (high glycemic, rapid)
- Pasta, bread (moderate glycemic)
- Fruit (fructose replenishes liver glycogen)

*Muscle Repair:*
- Complete proteins (meat, fish, eggs, dairy)
- Leucine-rich (whey, eggs, chicken)
- Collagen (bone broth, supplements) for connective tissue

**Hydration Recovery**

*Assessing Dehydration:*
- Weigh before and after training
- Each kg lost = ~1 liter fluid deficit
- Urine color: Should be pale yellow within 2-4 hours

*Rehydration Protocol:*
- Target: 1.5× fluid lost (accounts for continued losses)
- Include sodium: 500-1000mg per liter of fluid
- Timing: Spread over 2-4 hours (don't chug)
- Food helps: Meals contain water and sodium

*Signs of Inadequate Rehydration:*
- Persistent dark urine
- Continued thirst
- Headache
- Elevated heart rate at rest
- Poor performance in next session

title: Daily Nutrition Framework for Endurance Athletes
content:
**Calculating Daily Needs**

*Total Energy Expenditure (TEE):*

Step 1 - Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR):
- Mifflin-St Jeor equation:
- Men: (10 × weight kg) + (6.25 × height cm) - (5 × age) + 5
- Women: (10 × weight kg) + (6.25 × height cm) - (5 × age) - 161

Step 2 - Activity Multiplier:
- Sedentary + training: BMR × 1.4-1.5 + training calories
- Better approach: BMR × 1.3 + actual training expenditure

Step 3 - Training Expenditure:
- Easy cycling: ~400-600 kcal/hour
- Hard cycling: ~600-900 kcal/hour
- Easy running: ~80-100 kcal/mile
- Hard running: ~100-120 kcal/mile
- Swimming: ~400-700 kcal/hour

*Example Calculation:*
70 kg male, 175 cm, 35 years old
- BMR: (10×70) + (6.25×175) - (5×35) + 5 = 1,674 kcal
- Rest day TEE: 1,674 × 1.3 = 2,176 kcal
- Training day (2-hour ride at 600 kcal/hr): 2,176 + 1,200 = 3,376 kcal

**Macronutrient Distribution**

*Carbohydrate:*
- Light training day: 3-5 g/kg (210-350g for 70 kg athlete)
- Moderate training: 5-7 g/kg (350-490g)
- Heavy training: 7-10 g/kg (490-700g)
- Very heavy training: 10-12 g/kg (700-840g)

*Protein:*
- Standard: 1.4-1.6 g/kg (98-112g for 70 kg athlete)
- High intensity: 1.6-1.8 g/kg (112-126g)
- Weight loss phase: 1.8-2.2 g/kg (126-154g)

*Fat:*
- Minimum: 20% of calories (~60-80g typically)
- Typical range: 20-35% of calories
- Not lower than 0.8-1.0 g/kg

**Meal Timing and Distribution**

*General Framework:*

Breakfast (20-25% of daily calories):
- Include protein (eggs, yogurt, protein oatmeal)
- Carbs for morning training or recovery from previous day
- Example: Oatmeal with berries, eggs, toast

Lunch (25-30% of daily calories):
- Balanced meal: Protein + carbs + vegetables
- Supports afternoon training or recovery
- Example: Grain bowl with chicken, vegetables, avocado

Pre-Training Snack (if needed):
- 1-4 hours before training
- Easy-to-digest carbs + small protein
- Example: Banana + small yogurt, or toast with nut butter

Post-Training:
- See recovery nutrition section
- Snack immediately, meal within 2 hours

Dinner (25-30% of daily calories):
- Complete protein
- Complex carbs
- Vegetables
- Healthy fats
- Example: Salmon, sweet potato, roasted vegetables, olive oil

Evening Snack (optional):
- Slow protein before bed if needed
- Casein, cottage cheese, Greek yogurt
- Supports overnight recovery

**Micronutrient Priorities**

*Iron:*
- Critical for oxygen transport
- Athletes at higher risk of deficiency (especially female, vegetarian)
- Sources: Red meat, spinach, fortified cereals, legumes
- Consider: Periodic ferritin testing
- Note: Vitamin C enhances absorption; calcium/coffee inhibit

*Vitamin D:*
- Many athletes deficient (limited sun, indoor training)
- Important for: Bone health, immune function, muscle function
- Sources: Sun exposure, fatty fish, fortified foods, supplements
- Target: Blood level 40-60 ng/mL
- Supplementation: 1000-4000 IU daily if needed

*Calcium:*
- Bone health critical for impact sports
- Target: 1000-1500 mg/day
- Sources: Dairy, fortified alternatives, leafy greens
- Pair with vitamin D for absorption

*Magnesium:*
- Muscle function, sleep quality
- Often depleted by sweating
- Sources: Nuts, seeds, leafy greens, whole grains
- Supplementation: 200-400mg if needed (glycinate or citrate)

*Sodium:*
- Critical for athletes who sweat heavily
- Don't fear salt in diet if training hard
- Losses: 500-2000+ mg per hour of exercise
- Replace during and after exercise

**Hydration Framework**

*Baseline Daily Needs:*
- 30-40 ml per kg bodyweight (2.1-2.8 L for 70 kg)
- Add: Fluid lost during training
- Add: Extra in hot weather

*Monitoring Hydration:*
- Urine color: Pale yellow = adequate
- Morning weight: Consistent = adequate hydration
- Thirst: Respond to thirst (don't ignore or overdrink)

*During Training:*
- Goal: Limit weight loss to <2% bodyweight
- Start hydrated (pale urine before starting)
- Drink to thirst for sessions <90 min
- Planned hydration for longer sessions: 500-750 ml/hour typical

title: Evidence-Based Supplementation for Endurance Athletes
content:
**Supplement Tiers by Evidence**

*Tier 1: Strong Evidence, Recommended for Most Athletes*

Caffeine:
- Mechanism: Adenosine receptor antagonist, reduced perceived effort
- Dose: 3-6 mg/kg bodyweight (200-400mg for most)
- Timing: 30-60 minutes pre-exercise
- Effects: 2-4% performance improvement typical
- Duration: Peak 45-90 min, lasts 3-5 hours
- Notes: Individual response varies widely; some are non-responders
- Tolerance: Regular users may need higher doses
- Caution: Can disrupt sleep; avoid after early afternoon for most

Creatine Monohydrate:
- Mechanism: Increases phosphocreatine stores, ATP regeneration
- Dose: 3-5g daily (no loading required)
- Effects: Improved power, repeated sprint performance, possible recovery benefit
- Note: Water retention (1-2 kg) is normal, not fat
- Works for: All ages, genders, and training levels
- Endurance benefit: Modest for endurance, more for power/repeated efforts

Vitamin D (if deficient):
- Test before supplementing
- Target blood level: 40-60 ng/mL
- Dose: 1000-4000 IU daily to maintain
- Higher doses may be needed to correct deficiency
- Take with fat for absorption

Iron (if deficient):
- Test ferritin before supplementing
- Target ferritin: >30-50 ng/mL for athletes
- Supplementation: Only if deficient (excess is harmful)
- Take with vitamin C, away from coffee/tea/calcium

*Tier 2: Moderate Evidence, Beneficial for Some*

Beta-Alanine:
- Mechanism: Increases muscle carnosine, buffers acid
- Dose: 3-6g daily in divided doses (reduces tingling)
- Effects: Improved performance in 1-10 minute efforts
- Loading: Takes 4+ weeks to accumulate
- Note: Tingling (paresthesia) is harmless side effect
- Best for: Middle-distance events, high-intensity intervals

Beetroot Juice/Nitrates:
- Mechanism: Nitric oxide precursor, improves efficiency
- Dose: 300-500mg nitrate (500ml juice) or concentrated shot
- Timing: 2-3 hours before exercise
- Effects: 1-3% improvement in time to exhaustion
- Note: Antibacterial mouthwash blocks conversion
- Best for: Longer events, submaximal efforts

Sodium Bicarbonate:
- Mechanism: Extracellular buffer for acid
- Dose: 0.2-0.3 g/kg bodyweight
- Timing: 60-90 minutes pre-exercise
- Effects: Improved performance in 1-7 minute efforts
- Caution: GI distress common; test in training
- Strategy: Split doses or use sodium citrate alternative

*Tier 3: Emerging/Limited Evidence*

Omega-3 Fatty Acids:
- May reduce inflammation, support recovery
- Dose: 2-4g EPA+DHA daily
- Food sources preferred (fatty fish 2-3x/week)
- Supplement if diet insufficient

Tart Cherry Juice:
- May reduce DOMS and inflammation
- Dose: 250-350ml (or 30ml concentrate) twice daily
- Timing: Before and after exercise
- Evidence: Mixed but some positive studies

Collagen Peptides:
- May support connective tissue
- Dose: 10-15g daily with vitamin C
- Timing: 30-60 min before training or at night
- Evidence: Early research promising for tendons

*Tier 4: Waste of Money*

- BCAAs (if eating adequate protein)
- Glutamine (adequate from diet)
- Most testosterone boosters
- Fat burners (minimal effect, potential harm)
- 'Detox' products (no scientific basis)
- Most 'proprietary blends'

**Supplement Safety**

*Quality Assurance:*
- Look for third-party testing: NSF Certified for Sport, Informed Sport
- These test for banned substances and label accuracy
- Especially critical for competitive athletes
- Generic supplements may be contaminated or under-dosed

*Red Flags:*
- Claims that sound too good to be true
- Proprietary blends (hiding ingredient amounts)
- Not third-party tested
- Testimonials over science
- 'Natural' doesn't mean safe or effective

**Supplements During Different Phases**

Base/Off-Season:
- Vitamin D (if needed)
- Iron (if needed)
- Creatine (maintain)
- Focus on food-first approach

Build Phase:
- Continue above
- Add: Beta-alanine loading if targeting middle-distance
- Beetroot juice practice

Race Phase:
- Caffeine (practiced in training)
- Beetroot juice (day of or before)
- Sodium bicarbonate (if tolerated)
- Creatine (can continue or pause if weight-sensitive)

title: Body Composition Optimization for Endurance Performance
content:
**The Power-to-Weight Paradigm**

*Why Body Composition Matters:*
- Running: Every 1% bodyweight reduction ≈ 1% faster time (roughly)
- Cycling (climbing): Power-to-weight critical on grades
- Flat cycling/triathlon: Aerodynamics matters more than weight
- Swimming: Body composition affects buoyancy and drag

*However:*
- Performance ≠ lightest weight
- Underweight impairs power, recovery, health, immune function
- Optimal racing weight is individual
- Don't sacrifice health for weight

**Sustainable Fat Loss for Athletes**

*Rate of Loss:*
- Maximum: 0.5-1% bodyweight per week
- Optimal: 0.25-0.5% per week (preserves muscle, performance)
- Slower is better for athletes

*Caloric Deficit:*
- Moderate: 300-500 kcal/day below expenditure
- Aggressive (short-term only): 500-750 kcal/day
- Never below BMR
- Reduce from non-training calories first

*Macronutrient Adjustments:*

Protein (increase):
- 1.8-2.2 g/kg during deficit
- Preserves muscle mass
- Higher satiety
- Spread across 4-5 meals

Carbohydrate (maintain around training):
- Fuel training sessions fully
- Reduce on rest days
- Don't go extremely low (impairs training quality)

Fat (moderate):
- Don't go below 0.8 g/kg (hormone health)
- Reduce where flexible (cooking oils, fatty meats)
- Keep omega-3 sources

**Timing Fat Loss Phases**

*Best Times:*
- Off-season (no race priority)
- Early base phase (low intensity)
- After recovery period

*Worst Times:*
- Build phase (need energy for adaptation)
- Race week (glycogen depletion risk)
- During illness or injury recovery
- High life stress periods

*Duration:*
- Limit active fat loss phases to 8-12 weeks
- Take maintenance break, then continue if needed
- Don't be in constant deficit

**Monitoring Progress**

*Weighing:*
- Same time daily (morning, post-bathroom)
- Use 7-day rolling average (daily fluctuation normal)
- Weekly change of average is meaningful
- Expect plateaus; trust the process

*Body Composition:*
- DEXA scan: Gold standard, 1-2× per season
- Skinfolds: Consistent tester needed
- Progress photos: Helpful for visual tracking
- Measurements: Waist, hips (changes independent of scale)

*Performance:*
- Power-to-weight on climbs
- Running pace at same HR
- How clothes fit
- Subjective feel during training

**Warning Signs of Excessive Restriction**

*Physical:*
- Persistent fatigue beyond normal training fatigue
- Declining performance despite training
- Frequent illness/infection
- Slow recovery from sessions
- Loss of menstrual cycle (female athletes) - RED-S indicator
- Loss of libido
- Poor sleep
- Feeling cold frequently
- Hair loss

*Psychological:*
- Preoccupation with food and weight
- Anxiety around eating situations
- Rigid food rules
- Compensatory behaviors after eating
- Negative body image despite weight loss
- Social isolation due to food concerns

*If These Occur:*
- Stop active fat loss immediately
- Return to maintenance or surplus
- Seek professional support (sports dietitian, psychologist)
- Relative Energy Deficiency in Sport (RED-S) is serious

**Race Weight Strategy**

*Definition:* The lowest healthy weight where you perform best

*Finding Your Race Weight:*
- Track performance at different weights over seasons
- Note: Where do you perform best, not feel lightest?
- Individual sweet spot varies

*Race Week:*
- Should NOT be actively losing weight
- Maintain recent weight
- Carb loading adds 1-2 kg (glycogen + water) - expected and good
- Don't panic at race-week weight increase

*Post-Race:*
- Return to normal eating
- Some weight gain is normal
- Allow body to recover before next fat loss phase
